CONJUGATES: dusks (n. pl.) | dusked (v. past) | dusking (v. pres. part.)
ETYMOLOGY: From Middle English duske, influenced by Old English dox ('dark-colored') and Old Norse doskr ('dark, misty').

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: The time of day immediately following sunset when the sky is still slightly light but darkness is setting in; the darker stage of twilight.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 黄昏; 傍晚; 日落后天色变暗的时期。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: We always gather the children inside right before dusk.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 我们总是在黄昏前将孩子们叫进屋里。

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: A state or quality of dimness, shadow, or obscurity.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: 昏暗; 阴影; 晦暗的颜色或状态。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: A heavy dusk filled the corners of the old library.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 浓重的昏暗笼罩着这座旧图书馆的各个角落。

MEANINGS.DEF_EN: (Of light or surroundings) to become dim or dark; to approach the period of twilight.
MEANINGS.DEF_ZH: (使) 变暗; 变昏; 到达黄昏时分。
MEANINGS.SENT_EN: The summer sky began to dusk earlier toward the end of August.
MEANINGS.SENT_ZH: 夏日的天空在八月底开始更早地变暗。

REGISTER: General usage, often used in literature and descriptions of nature or time.
